li.a: Who We Are: The Dalton Difference

img.alt: Text that reads: Update center for COVID-19 or coronavirus

div.h3: Dalton Public Schools will be closed through the end of the school year.
div.p: Extended Digital Learning will resume on Monday, April 6. We will continue to collaborate with local health officials and seek advice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as we work together to navigate this situation.

In an effort to meet the needs of our students who rely on school meals, Dalton Public Schools will be providing breakfast and lunch at no cost to all children 18 and younger March 16-27th. Our school nutrition team will be preparing meals and traveling bus routes with drivers to distribute them. Bus drivers will follow their usual routes twice a day to distribute breakfast and lunch.

p.a: Click here for more information including the bus routes and the pick-up locations.

div.p: Students should follow their digital learning plans while schools are closed.

p.a: Please click here for more information on digital learning.

div.p: Need Wifi?
We are working on external WIFI access at our school sites. So far we have WIFI access in the following locations:
Park Creek Elementary in the front parking lot
City Park Elementary in the front parking lot
As we install additional locations we will send out communication. Any school-issued device will connect in these locations.

li.a: April 14, 2020 - Important Updates from Dr. Scott

h2.a: April 14, 2020 - Important Updates from Dr. Scott

div.p: School and district leaders have been in ongoing collaboration about how to approach grading during this unprecedented school closure. Extraordinary times require an extraordinary response. As we all feel our way through the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year, our efforts to ensure that we have met the academic needs of our students must be balanced against the social and emotional health of our students, their families, our faculties and staff and the acknowledgement that not all students have the same degree of access to learning and learning supports away from school.

Student work submitted during the school closure and graded (effective March 16) can be applied to a student’s overall grade/average, if it adds value to the student’s base grade/average as of March 13. No grade or final assessments given after March 13 will negatively impact a student’s base grade.
Not all work is designed to be graded but rather for reinforcement and practice of content and skills.
New standards will be introduced so that students will have an opportunity to have exposure to content that will help prepare them to begin the 2020 – 2021 school year.
Students should complete digital assignments and assessments as assigned.
Teachers will stop assigning new work on Friday, May 8. The week of May 11 – 15 is reserved for making up missed assignments and final assessments/projects/presentations.
Questions about grading or assignments should be directed to your student’s teacher(s).

p.strong: GUIDANCE FOR HIGH SCHOOL SENIORS/ GRADES 6 – 12 STUDENTS

div.p: The Dalton Board of Education Policy IHF still stands for graduation requirements. Students must have earned 24 credits in order to earn a high school diploma. Transcripts and other documentation may be obtained as usual through your high school counseling office.
Seventy (70) is the minimum passing grade for all courses taught 6 – 12 and numerical credit will be recorded and maintained.

p.strong: GUÍA PARA GRADOS/GRADUACIÓN PARA FAMILIAS DE DPS

div.p: Los líderes de las escuelas y del distrito han estado colaborando en cómo llegar a un acuerdo sobre grados durante este cierre de escuela sin precedente. Tiempos extraordinarios requieren una respuesta extraordinaria. Mientras avanzamos en lo que queda del año escolar 2019-2020 esperamos haber cumplido en nuestros esfuerzos de satisfacer las necesidades académicas de nuestros estudiantes al igual que la salud social y emocional de nuestros estudiantes, sus familias, y nuestra facultad. Tomando en cuenta que no todos nuestros estudiantes tienen el mismo acceso a aprendizaje y el apoyo académico en casa hemos decidido lo siguiente.

Tareas de los estudiantes que han sido entregadas durante el cierro de las escuelas (efectivo el 16 de marzo) se podrá aplicar al promedio/grado del estudiante, si le agrega valor al grado base/promedio a partir del 13 de marzo. Ningún grado o evaluación que fue asignada después del 13 de marzo impactara negativamente el grado base del estudiante.
No todas las tareas son diseñadas para recibir un grado si no para reforzar la práctica del contenido y las habilidades.
Nuevos estándares serán introducidos para que los estudiantes tengan la oportunidad de ser expuestos al contenido que ayudara prepararlos para comenzar el año escolar 2020-2021.
Los estudiantes deben terminar e entregar tareas e evaluaciones digitales como sean asignadas.
Los maestros(as) dejaran de asignar nuevas tareas el viernes, 8 de mayo. La semana del 11 al 15 de mayo será reservada para entregar tareas que faltan y evaluaciones/proyectos/presentaciones finales.
Preguntas sobre grados o tareas deberán ser dirigidas a los maestros(as) de su(s) estudiante(s).

p.strong: GUÍA PARA ESTUDIANTES DE ULITMO ANO/ GRADO DEL 6º AL 12º

div.p: La Póliza IHF de la Mesa Directiva de Educación de Dalton todavía queda en lugar sobre los requisitos de graduación. Estudiantes deberán tener 24 créditos en orden para recibir un diploma de la preparatoria. Los expedientes de grados y otra documentación pueden ser obtenidas por medio de la oficina de consejería.
Setenta (70) es el grado mínimo para pasar todos los cursos ensenados del 6º al 12º grado y el crédito numérico será grabado y mantenido.

On Thursday, March 26, 2020, Governor Kemp signed an Executive Order mandating school closure through Friday, April 24. Dalton Public Schools will observe this order and continue our digital learning plans as well as our student breakfast and lunch delivery program until that time.

In an effort to meet the needs of our students who rely on school meals, Dalton Public Schools will be providing breakfast and lunch at no cost to all children 18 and younger March 16-27th. Our school nutrition team will be preparing meals and traveling bus routes with drivers to distribute them. Bus drivers will follow their usual routes twice a day to distribute breakfast and lunch.

p.a: Click here for more information including the bus routes and the pick-up locations.

div.p: Children can pick up food from any location. You do not have to be enrolled at the school in order to get a meal. If you are visiting from another school district, you are eligible to receive meals in Dalton.
DPS will continue this service to our students should this closure extend beyond spring break (March 30th - April 3rd). Meals will not be served during Spring Break.

Throughout the coronavirus crisis, Dalton Public Schools has been committed to making decisions based on the most accurate and recent information available. Therefore, in light of Governor Kemp’s declaration on Saturday of an unprecedented public health emergency and the sharp increase in the confirmed number of statewide cases overnight, Dalton Public Schools will be closing all schools beginning Monday, March 16th through Friday, March 27th and implementing our Digital Learning Plan for all students.

Our scheduled Spring Break will be observed from Monday, March 30th through Friday, April 3rd. We will continue to collaborate with local health officials and seek advice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as we work together to navigate this situation.

We know school closures create unique challenges for many of our students and their families. Our administration is working to determine ways we can continue to serve students and families who depend on school nutrition for food. This information will be communicated quickly as plans are confirmed. Please check the district and school websites and social media for more information and updates.
Thank you for your support of our students, staff and schools during this unprecedented time.

p.strong: Statement from State School Superintendent Richard Woods on COVID-19

div.p: “After being notified that an employee had been diagnosed with COVID-19 (coronavirus), Fulton County Schools made the decision to close all schools today and to make an announcement about next steps by 5 p.m. today. We support this decision and thank Superintendent Mike Looney for his leadership and for taking care to ensure students’ safety.

We are advising all Georgia school districts to continue following the guidance of the Georgia Department of Public Health and their local boards of health. At this time, school closures are not recommended for other areas.

All school districts should continue to take preventative measures, including providing ample time for students and staff to wash their hands and developing plans to continue student learning should your school district need to close for several days.

Parents should keep children who are sick at home – don’t send them to school. Teach your children to wash their hands with soap and water for 20 seconds and to stay at least three feet away from people who are sick.

Georgians can be confident the safety of our students is our first priority. I thank Governor Kemp for acting proactively to protect all Georgians. We will continue to work closely with him and with Public Health to ensure schools have the most up-to-date information, resources, and support regarding COVID-19."
The Georgia Department of Public Health has put together a PowerPoint with information and resources regarding COVID-19. To view this PowerPoint, click here:

p.a: GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH COVID-19 POWERPOINT

p.strong: New Cases of COVID-19 Identified in Georgia

div.p: ATLANTA – There have been a number of developments overnight regarding COVID-19 in Georgia. Governor Kemp and DPH Commissioner Kathleen E. Toomey, M.D., M.P.H. want to remind all Georgians that the overall risk of COVID-19 to the general public remains low and there is no evidence of community spread of COVID-19 in Georgia at this time.

The Georgia Department of Public Health (DPH) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have confirmed two additional cases of COVID-19 in Georgia. Testing was done by the CDC, prior to the Georgia Public Health Laboratory (GPHL) having the capacity to test for COVID-19.

One individual is from Cobb County and recently returned from Italy and is isolated at home. The other individual is from Fulton County and is hospitalized. The source of this individual’s exposure is unclear at this time.

Additionally, DPH is awaiting confirmatory testing on a presumptive positive test for COVID-19 in a resident of Gwinnett County. The initial testing was completed by GPHL March 6. The individual recently returned from Italy and was self-monitoring at home, and is now isolated at home.
CDC testing has confirmed the presumptive positive test for COVID-19 in a resident of Floyd County. The original testing was done by GPHL March 5. The individual is hospitalized.

“Federal and state officials continue to work closely together to conduct testing and determine the extent of exposure for confirmed cases of COVID-19. The risk to Georgians remains low. We ask Georgians to stay vigilant, utilize best practices to mitigate health risk, and remain calm,” said Governor Kemp.

“DPH is prepared to mitigate the spread of this virus in our state, and we are aggressively working to identify anyone who may have had contact with these individuals,” said Kathleen E. Toomey, M.D., M.P.H., DPH commissioner. “Despite these new cases, the overall risk of COVID-19 to the general public remains low; but each new case of COVID-19 in Georgia reinforces the fact we should all be practicing basic prevention measures that are extremely effective in limiting the spread of COVID-19 and all respiratory illnesses."
div.li: Wash your hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
div.p: If you have recently traveled to areas where there are ongoing outbreaks of COVID-19 and develop fever with cough and shortness of breath within 14 days of your travel, or if you have had contact with someone who is suspected to have COVID-19, stay home and call your health care provider or local health department right away. Be sure to call before going to a doctor’s office, emergency room, or urgent care center and tell them about your recent travel and your symptoms.

For accurate and reliable information about COVID-19 log on to: dph.georgia.gov/novelcoronavirus or cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/index.html. Find answers to frequently asked questions at cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/index.html.

Dalton Public Schools takes the safety and wellbeing of all of our students and staff very seriously. As you may know, over the last several days the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has issued several statements regarding the need for Americans to prepare for the possibility of the Coronavirus(COVID-19) to spread in the United States. First identified in December in Wuhan, China, the Coronavirus is a respiratory illness. At this time, the CDC has said there is no reason from a clinical standpoint to be alarmed.

Our district has been in contact with the North Georgia Health District and is monitoring information from the CDC on preventative measures and the latest information on the situation. While the CDC reports that the immediate risk of this new virus to the American public is believed to be low at this time, everyone can do their part to help respond to this emerging public health threat.
As best practice for overall health and to prevent the spread of illness, the following steps should be taken by your and your children:

ul.li: Wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60 percent alcohol
Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands
Avoid contact with people who are sick
Stay home when you are sick
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe

div.p: In addition, our schools are cleaned and disinfected daily as part of ongoing custodial services in the schools, which is another recommendation from the health department.

Dalton Public Schools will continue to follow all recommendations from federal, state and local entities concerning the Coronavirus. We will continue to update this page with any new information as it becomes available.

li.a: What to do if you are infected?

div.p: Student and staff safety is our top priority at Dalton Public Schools. If you have a question, concern or comment about any health or safety issue, please let us know.
